title: Java Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at APA
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed with the American Psychological Association (APA) for a Java Enigneer role. It was your typical developer interview where the interviewers fire off pre-planned technical questions without much respect to the interviewee and are skeptical of any work experience you describe without any basis for being skeptical. The APA also has unrealistic expectations of wanting to hire a senior Java developer with greenfield experience but not labeling the opportunity as a senior position with greenfield experience required. At the same time, the APA only is offering a non-senior developer max salary of $120K for the role. The APA apparently justify the salary on the basis that they're a nonprofit organization. To make matters weirder, during the interview, the interviewers insisted that I was on camera for them without all of the interviewers being on camera in return. So if you want to work for a company that requires you to be on camera when other people aren't on camera and work for below market rates with unrealistic expectations, then the APA is the company for you.
Interview Questions: Questions related to Spring Security

title: Peer Review Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at APA (Washington, DC) in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions: The job was originally posted in October, which was when I applied, but then it was reposted in December. I decided to revamp my resume with the hopes that a more concise resume will get past their ATS. And perhaps it did because they reached out to me for an interview two weeks later, but I can’t be sure of that—regardless, I was first contacted by Human Resources for a phone screening. But the first question was about my residency, APA hires people that live within the DMV nexus for tax purposes. I had to move out of the (D)MV because of the pandemic, so I was a bit thrown off because that was the first question. And there’s nothing you can do about that kind of situation without a job and salary. Even so, the phone screening went well but they moved forward with other candidates. I had to reach out and figure out the status of the timeline in mid-January in order to get this update.
Interview Questions: Name one strength and one weakness.

title: Managing Editor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at APA
Interview Descriptions: Was contacted by the hiring manager well after business hours to schedule a very short information interview via video. Was asked a few questions, some professional/work related, others not. This raised several yellow flags for me. Was contacted again after business hours for a second interview and asked to put together a presentation using current APA materials and products for what was essentially a job audition.  Although the presentation was supposed to be "high level" preparing for that type of presentation would take 3 to 4 hours, at least. I was given 1 business day to turn the presentation around. This raised several red flags, including being asked for unpaid consulting, short timeframe of the ask, and no gaurentee that my intellectual property would not be used if I was not hired. In the future, I would avoid asking candidates for job auditions and remember that candidates are vetting you as an employer and boss just as much as you are vetting them.
Interview Questions: How would your friends describe you?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at APA
Interview Descriptions: I received a call to come in to interview for the position I had applied for. The recruiter mentioned that it was short notice - they wanted me to come in that same week, 2 days from the day I received their call. While not the most convenient, I have experienced other organizations calling me in for an interview with short notice so it was not a huge deal, although not ideal. I had work commitments I could not cancel last minute, so the recruiter said he would follow up with more dates in the coming days. A couple days later, the recruiter followed up with potential dates and time slots for the following week and asked me to pick one. He specifically stated that he would follow up with a confirmation of the date and time once he received my response. I received no such confirmation. I followed up via email and phone and left a voice message, yet still no call back nor confirmation, not even on the day that I had selected as my interview slot. I could only assume the interview was not taking place as I had no idea where exactly the interview would be held, with whom I would be meeting, if the interviewers even had the interview on their schedule, nothing because I did not receive this information, even when asked for it. If I do receive some sort of follow-up or offer to reschedule, I'm not sure that this experience reflects well on the company and how much value they place on potential employees that spend a lot of energy and time applying and waiting for responses from potential employers.
Interview Questions: I wasn't asked any questions because the interview did not take place.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at APA (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: It was very fast for me- I submitted an application via their online system on a Friday and was called the next Tuesday (four days later) offered an interview. I booked a time for that Friday. Spent about 20-30 minutes speaking with an HR person first about my prior experience, qualifications, education, etc and answered a few basic questions about why I wanted to work this job and with the APA. Then I interviewed with my specific hiring manager and we got on quite well, so it lasted a good 1.5 hrs. Very positive, open honest discussion about expectations on both sides, my qualifications, strengths, weaknesses, and what the job entailed. Was called back that very day to find out that I was a finalist and that they’d be checking my references. References are done electronically through the same application site. You input the contact info, name, title, etc, of the references, and then click a button that sends them a message asking them to fill out a pre-made reference form. Less than 10 days later, I got a verbal offer and after tentatively accepting, got the formal offer letter w/ salary and start date.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this specific job?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at APA (Washington, DC) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied to the job about three weeks after it was posted. About a month later, after I presumed I wasn't in the running, they called me to offer me an interview. I went in and met with the HR business manager, who asked me a few very basic behavioral questions for 10-15 minutes or less. I then met with the hiring manager, who also asked very simple, "what-would-you-do-if" scenario questions. From there, it became more of a casual conversation where I asked about APA culture and an average workday and what the best things about APA are. I was doing pretty well, so they brought in the head of the department to meet with me to talk about the position and my interests, also fairly informal. I was free to go afterwards, the meeting spreading to about 45 minutes. Three days later, my HR rep contacted me to say she would be emailing my references. About two weeks passed (I think my HR manager was out of town for a week) and I received an offer over the phone.

What is your experience with sensitive documents?

title: Coordinator (Administration) Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at APA (Washington, DC) in Aug 2010
Interview Descriptions:
I interviewed with the APA a few weeks ago. It was a relatively easy interview process. First, I met with the HR Director; I actually shown up about 15 min. early for the interview and she had me waiting in the lobby for another 40 minutes! She was extremely nice though; she just looked over my resume and took down a few notes while making small talk. She then told me that I was to interview with my would-be supervisor. So, I waited another few minutes until my interviewer came to get me and take me to her floor. She was very nice and funny; although she read off a prepared sheet of questions, it was a very easy and relaxed interview. She asked me the usual questions: What were your responsibilities at your previous job? Why should I hire you over any other applicant? 
Just be prepared to answer questions about your job capabilities rather than so much about the company. However, you should read up on the specific office that you are interviewing for (i.e. education, women, accreditation, etc.). Each office has its own specific webpage seperate from apa.org.
After interviewing with my would-be supervisor, she took me over to her boss' office for the final stage of the interview. Her boss was very sweet and asked me just a few questions, one of them being "What would you do if you were in a situation at work in which a colleague had a differing opinion regarding how to handle a specific project?" 
After the interview, my would-be supervisor asked me to write her an e-mail explaining why I wanted the job. She was very straight-forward and said it was to measure my follow-up and writing skills. About 10 days (which was a little longer than I should have waited) after sending the first e-mail I sent a second. I got a response right away saying that they were still in the interviewing process and I should expect a call soon. I know that they have called up at least one of my references, so I am hoping for a job offer this week.
Interview Questions: What kind of manager do you prefer?
